body: Across Brooklyn over the last year, battles for change and preservation rippled through the borough from Red Hook to Dead Horse Bay, in strikingly grass-roots fashion. The neighborhood crusades were large and small, the issues profound and esthetic. There were victories and defeats and, for some, nebulous results. But whatever the outcome of the
title: A Ripple of Neighborhood Crusades on Issues of All Kinds

body: To the Editor: Your Dec. 8 article ''Developers' Hazard: Legal Hardball'' failed to mention that the Board of Standards and Appeals (B.S.A.) twice unanimously rejected the Loehmann's Seaport Plaza in Brooklyn because the Sheepshead Bay waterfront was designated a ''Special District,'' which by law prohibited such large retail development directly
title: Battle Over Loehmann's Plaza

body: If New York City is to become a harbor for floating casinos that conduct their gambling operations in international waters, it makes sense for the city government to learn about who is going into the business. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is thus right to try to stop the activities of a new company that suddenly began taking gamblers from Sheepshead Bay
title: Brooklyn's Offshore Casino

body: The Giuliani administration went to court yesterday to try to block the owners of a casino ship from using a Brooklyn pier, a legal maneuver intended to stop the cruises until the city can scrutinize the background of its owners. But the company that operates the casino, Bay Cruises of Sheepshead Bay, vowed to continue twice-daily excursions from
title: City Seeks Way to Halt Casino Cruises

body: For months, Michael Kornblum told curious residents and politicians that the pier his new company was busily renovating on the Sheepshead Bay waterfront in Brooklyn would be used for a dinner-and-dancing cruise boat that would bring some high-class entertainment to an area struggling to revive itself. Then, like a magician pulling away the cape,
title: Mystery of a Casino Boat Matches the Style of Its Owner

body: NEW YORK How School Change Took Shape Eager to seize the reins of the nation's largest school system, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew arrived in New York City 14 months ago and quickly learned just how little power he had. But in the last several months, an orchestration of circumstance and strategy made a reorganization of the city's schools
title: METRO DIGEST

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he planned to seek a court order to stop a floating casino from running day trips from Brooklyn until the backgrounds of the cruise operators could be scrutinized. Lawyers for the city are to appear tomorrow in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to argue that the cruise line, Bay Cruises, violated local
title: Mayor Plans Suit to Control A Casino Ship

body: Back in 1975, a lawsuit brought by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People resulted in a landmark civil rights ruling: a Federal judge ordered the desegregation of Mark Twain Junior High School in Coney Island, a predominantly black school in a sea of mostly white schools. That September, over the protests of many parents in
title: Parents Say School for Gifted Is Mostly Magnet for Whites

body: The roulette wheels spun, the chips clicked and clacked and the gamblers pleaded with the dice. But the tipoff that this was not Monte Carlo, or even Atlantic City, was on the waitresses' trays. Beside the glasses of scotch and white wine were little purple-and-white packets of Dramamine. So it was on the maiden voyage of the Liberty I, the
title: A Casino Boat Sails From Brooklyn, Leaving Debate Ashore

body: The Rev. Dr. David Munroe Cory died on Wednesday, having spent many of his 93 years embracing socialism, preaching to American Indians in their own tongue and generally dashing any notion that he was a blue-blooded Presbyterian. Dr. Cory, who had recently suffered a stroke, died of pneumonia at the Norwegian Christian Home in Sunset Park, Brooklyn,
title: The Rev. Dr. David M. Cory, 93, Preacher of Social Reform

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was creating a commission to oversee operators of gambling cruise ships that sail out of New York City, and to consider how the city can collect fees or taxes from such businesses. The move was prompted by a new venture, announced last week, in which a gambling boat will sail for daily cruises from a
title: Giuliani Studies Regulating Gambling Cruises

body: Smoke on the Water Q. I read that an early automobile speed record was set at a raceway right here in Brooklyn. Where? A. In the days when gritty, goggled drivers in cloth caps hunched over their steering wheels, roared around wooden tracks in cars that looked like soapbox racers, auto speed records were set at the Sheepshead Speedway in Sheepshead
title: F.Y.I.

body: Gambling in the metropolitan region still takes a little effort. From New York, a trip to Atlantic City or Foxwoods in Connecticut can take up to three hours in a car or bus. Cruises that leave from Manhattan's West Side can take just as long to reach the three-mile limit offshore -- where gambling is unregulated -- before the first cut of the
title: Coming: High-Seas Shortcut to High Stakes

body: NO one knows yet whether the Columbus Circle redevelopment project will wind up as a Sears or Sotheby's, a Reebok health spa or the Museum of American Folk Art, a swank hotel or a high-priced condominium apartment tower. But there is one safe bet. It will almost certainly wind up in court. With months to go before the Metropolitan Transportation
title: Developers' Hazard: Legal Hardball

body: Sheila Dean will not say, not out loud, why Thanksgiving is so special this year. She will hint at the reason, whisper about it. For Anthony Dean, the man she lives with and plans to marry and whose name she has already taken, there will be no Thanksgiving next year, the doctors say. Mr. Dean is dying of cancer. With luck, he will see Christmas,
title: A Meal With Family Alleviates the Burden For a Dying Man

body: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is directing school officials to begin to evaluate about 15,000 special-education children with the goal of moving as many as possible into regular classrooms starting as early as next fall, he said yesterday. The evaluations, to start in January, would be the first phase of Dr. Crew's proposed overhaul of the city's
title: Chancellor Plans Evaluations For Special-Education Shift

body: To the Editor: After reading your Nov. 21 news article on the proposals to develop the waterfront of Greenport, L.I., I'm for nominating its Mayor, David E. Kapell, for Mayor of New York City. He is a man who has vision and common sense, something that New York City's leaders are lacking. While Mayor Kapell of Greenport sees no interest in a
title: On the Waterfront

body: In the best science fiction movies, there are parallel universes, worlds within worlds, secrets locked in forgotten codes. And so it is with the New York subways, which were envisioned to go far more places -- in a skein of routes that might dazzle present-day straphangers -- under bold plans that have faded into distant memory. Some of this
title: Subway Planners' Lofty Ambitions Are Buried as Dead-End Curiosities

body: BELIEVING that the market for affordably priced cooperatives in New York City boroughs outside of Manhattan is beginning to improve, some developers who have taken over troubled buildings are selling apartments again. Indicative of this willingness to return to the market are the activities of three separate development groups that have worked out
title: Lower-priced co-ops sell again in once-troubled buildings in boroughs outside Manhattan.

body: Loehmann's Discretion Discretion is the glue that holds together the relationship between off-price stores like Loehmann's and its image-conscious suppliers who are top designers. title: Patterns

title: The Flames Are Fanning Against Racism

body: To the Editor: While I can't speak for all neighborhoods, I can assure you that sneakers hanging from phone wires (F.Y.I., Aug. 18) dates back to at least 1956 in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. You didn't wear sneakers to school then but had to wear them in gym. No lockers were available so you carried your sneakers to school. Many boys would tie the
title: Sneakers on Phone Wires Had Innocent Origins

body: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on Aug. 18 about a Holocaust memorial under construction in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, misstated the origin of its design. Markers commemorating 11 specific groups persecuted by the Nazis were part of the original design by the architect, George P. Vellonakis, but have since been dropped. The architect did
title: Correction

body: WHEN she first arrived from the Soviet Union seven years ago, Natalya Novikova cleaned other people's homes. Now she is president of a travel agency and owns her own $244,000 home in Brooklyn -- purchased with a mortgage that offers flexibility for even higher steps on America's ladder to success. It was Mrs. Novikova who supported the family
title: Fitting the Mortgage to the Need

body: Kathleen Collins looked across the ring and saw her disheveled opponent standing a few feet away. The woman's hair was matted and her face was puffy, swelling by the moment. How nicely, she thought, Andrea DeShong's pink boxing gloves went with her red welts. The 2,517 patrons who filled more than half of the Theater last night may have come to see
title: Brightest Stars at Garden Are the Women

body: A city-funded Holocaust memorial under construction in Sheepshead Bay has become the focus of a debate about how to note the various groups who fell victim to the Nazis. The Parks Department architect who designed the memorial -- a 14 1/2-foot steel tower surrounded by about 40 granite tablets resembling tombstones -- proposed adding 10 tablets as
title: A Rift Opens Over 'Other Victims' at Holocaust Memorial

body: ANN FERRAR was riding her 650-cubic-centimeter BMW R65 motorcycle along the country roads just west of Westhampton near her home in Mastic Beach on a sunny day last week. I'm riding behind her, watching a photographer film her balance a bike that seems large, but not ungainly, under her 5-foot-2-inch frame. She drives the bike slowly for the shoot,
title: Hear Me Roar, a Woman's Symphony on the Road

body: Edward Murphy spent much of last weekend caring for his wife as she recovered from surgery at the couple's Brooklyn home. But on Sunday, he told her he was going fishing for a few hours, and put a six-pack of beer into a cooler before taking off. When he returned six hours later, his wife, Gail, went out to the porch of their Sheepshead Bay home,
title: Woman, 47, Is Held in Husband's Killing

body: A con man posing as a police detective or F.B.I. agent, complete with a gold shield and a tough demeanor, has bilked a string of elderly victims of more than $20,000 of their savings in a two-week crime spree, police officials said yesterday. In eight separate daytime incidents in locations ranging from a wealthy uptown Manhattan block to a
title: Man Posing as Police Detective Bilks Elderly Victims at Banks

body: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to allow free transfers between subways and buses throughout New York City beginning next year, officials said yesterday, in what promises to be the biggest change in transit service since the three separate subway systems were united in 1940. "Hopefully, it will be next July," said E. Virgil Conway,
title: M.T.A. Planning Free Transfers Between Subways and Buses

body: The basketball sailed over the high stone wall along St. Johns Place in Brooklyn, just missing the statue of Mary and the baby Jesus that rises forlornly above a block of graffiti-scarred row houses. The ball's 13-year-old owner walked cautiously to the black iron gates of the Monastery of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, pressed a button and retreated to
title: Medieval Fortress of Spirituality;Cloaked in Mystery, Brooklyn Nuns Do Their Work: Prayer

body: To the Editor: The unwritten rule allowing double parking while the streets are being cleaned makes sense (F.Y.I., May 5). Would it be asking too much to go one step further and allow re-parking as soon as you see the sweeper doing its job or you see the brush marks that show it has passed through? HAROLD ROTH Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn
title: Why Not Allow Parking Once Street Is Cleaned?

body: In chess, in which the arcane, intense battles on the board often pale beside the rivalries away from it, the most controversial figure may not be the 33-year-old world champion, Garry Kasparov, a globe-trotting Muscovite businessman and political commentator whose charismatic, camera-friendly arrogance and hubris are matched only by his
title: Chess in Black and White: 2 Emigres, Father and Son;Pugnacious Manager and Shy, Brilliant Player

body: Glassy-eyed from poring over textbooks, most law school students do not have time for page-turners that command six-figure advances from major publishing houses. title: Presumed Best Seller;Law Student Wins Top Money for First Novel

body: Knowing next to no one, Mesut Yaktubay stepped off the plane from Turkey two weeks ago and became an instant regular at Sunny Grocery, a postage-stamp-sized market on an unremarkable corner in Sunnyside, Queens. He does not come for the fava bean paste dip, the fried liver, the shiny pistachio-dappled squares of sobiyet pastry or anything else that
title: In the Queens Mosaic, A Turkish Inlay;Community Takes Root in Sunnyside

body: YANKEES fans may not always find George Steinbrenner a bundle of laughs, but a hefty slice of America does. While the real George Steinbrenner -- known as The Boss to his minions and to tabloid
title: ON THE SET WITH/The 'Seinfeld' Steinbrenner;The Head Yankee, Deconstructed

body: A chart in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday with an article about the revitalization of Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, misstated the addresses of a restaurant and of a shopping plaza that is under construction. The restaurant, Lundy's, is at 1901 Emmons Avenue; the shopping center, Loehmann's Plaza, is at 2027-2063 Emmons Avenue.
title: Corrections

body: City officials had hoped to unveil a simple, ecologically friendly pilot project before Earth Day next month: Bicyclists and joggers would have full command of the road that snakes through Prospect Park, which would be open to cars only during rush hour in the summer. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN BEACH/SHEEPSHEAD BAY;Bureaucratic Static Jams a Park Traffic Reduction Program

body: The family of a 16-year-old youth who was shot in the head and killed last March by a New York City police officer in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, has settled a Federal civil suit with the city for $400,000 but is still calling on the United States Attorney to file criminal charges against the officer. title: Settlement Reached in Police Shooting Suit

body: Yefim Slusker, known to his clientele as Jimmy, can't always remember the names of his "very, very famous" customers. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS;A Shoemaker's Opus: Footwear Fit for a Prima Donna

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;For Twins, A Grimm Odyssey In a Heavy Metal World

body: A livery-cab driver was found shot to death in the front seat of his car on a Brooklyn street early yesterday, the police said. The police were investigating whether the killing of Mikhail Sharov, 42 -- the fourth of a livery-cab driver in New York this year -- was related to the other three slayings, which ballistics tests showed were committed
title: Another Livery-Cab Driver Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn

body: The police have formed a homicide task force to determine whether a single person carried out the killings of four livery-cab drivers over the last 13 months. A police official who spoke on condition of anonymity said ballistics tests confirmed that three of the livery drivers were killed by the same .22-caliber gun. The latest victim, Mancoor
title: Inquiry on Cabby Killings

body: Mischa Frankel celebrated his 84th birthday on Feb. 1 in the Virgin Islands, attending a seminar at the Omega Institute, dancing to African drumming and leading a group in an old folk song with the refrain, "Love is something that if you give it away, you end up having more." That might well be his credo; for the last half-century Mr. Frankel has
title: At 84, Not Missing a Beat

body: Prompted by a rash of illegal betting on the Super Bowl, about 100 law enforcement officers and members of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office raided 14 gambling operations Saturday in Brooklyn and Queens and on Staten Island. The police arrested 26 people and confiscated about $25,000 in cash, as well as telephones, satellite television
title: Police Arrest 26 in Raids On 14 Gambling Operations

body: Until 1991 the pop music charts were notoriously unreliable. Paying off record store employees with free albums, concert tickets and even vacations and washing machines was the standard music-business method of manipulating record sales figures. Even the Billboard magazine charts, considered the most prestigious in the business, were compiled from
title: Are Pop Charts Manipulated?

body: Well, guess who's here!" Phil Donahue crowed to his studio audience yesterday afternoon, his eyebrows leaping, his snowy forelock flapping as he executed the talk-show equivalent of a rabbit trick. "None other than Salman Rushdie!" And there he was, the elusive author with a price on his head, seven years in hiding, gabbing on "Donahue," doing
title: Rushdie Out of Hiding, on 'Donahue'

body: More than three years have passed since the Democratic Senate primary in which Geraldine A. Ferraro lost a bruising contest in a quest to become the first woman to be a United States Senator from New York. The former Vice-Presidential candidate walked away from that race hurt, embittered and shunning elective politics. But now Ms. Ferraro is openly
title: After Retreating From Politics, Ferraro Is Talking About Another Try

body: The New York region rolled up its sleeves yesterday and tackled the gigantic task of coming out from under the Blizzard of '96 as airports and roads reopened, business resumed and people at least tried to return to work. Thousands of commuters jammed suburban buses and train lines, waiting hours to get to work. Bank branches opened, mail was
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE OVERVIEW;Snow-Clogged Region Stirs Back to Life As Novelty Fades and Frustrations Mount

body: Lawyers, stock clerks and dozens of others who consider themselves essential to 20th-century commerce stood in the waterlogged lobby of the Long Island Rail Road station here this morning, chatting, reading, sipping coffee. It was a scene of suburban civility and restraint. Then came a rumble from the distance, and all dignity was lost. En masse,
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE COMMUTERS;For Commuters, That Trek To Work Seemed Endless

body: An unknown person or persons took a track loader -- a heavy metal-tracked earthmover similar to a bulldozer -- from a construction site in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, shortly before 11 P.M. on Sunday night and rumbled up several blocks to the Chemical Bank branch at 2623 East 17th Street. title: A Bank Is Robbed With an Earthmover

body: When Lundy's closed 16 years ago in Sheepshead Bay, it was one of Brooklyn's best-loved institutions. When it reopened (under new owners) just after Thanksgiving, the response was immediate. Although the restaurant seats 400 people, a sign on the door read, "Reservations necessary during December." Some things have changed. Sheepshead Bay is no
title: Diner's Journal
